LEAD: Two geochemists who did pioneering work on the chemical relationships of the oceans and the atmosphere and the land have been awarded the 1987 Vetlesen Prize in the earth sciences.
Two geochemists who did pioneering work on the chemical relationships of the oceans and the atmosphere and the land have been awarded the 1987 Vetlesen Prize in the earth sciences.

Dr. Wallace S. Broecker of Columbia University's Lamont-Doherty Geological Observatory and Dr. Harmon Craig of the Scripps Institution of Oceanography at the University of California, in San Diego, shared the $100,000 prize.
The prize was established in 1959 to offer earth scientists an award comparable to the Nobel Prize.
In the mid-1970's, Dr. Broecker, 55 years old, helped revive interest in the ''greenhouse effect,'' warning that carbon dioxide released from burning fuels would spur global warming.
Dr. Craig, 61, showed that atmospheric methane had doubled in the past 300 years, a finding important to studies of climate warming.
